title: How to Make Cheese Straws

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: You need to preheat the oven at 325 degrees. Take 4 baking sheets and lightly spray them with cooking spray. Set them aside.

steps.headline: Prepare the cheese.
steps.description: Leave your butter and cheese on the counter for a few hours to soften them. Once they are softened, put them in a large bowl. Using an electric mixer, beat the butter and cheese together until they look like cream cheese. This should take about 15-30 minutes. This is easiest if you have a standing mixer. This allows you to leave the mixture to beat instead of holding a hand mixer.

steps.headline: Make the dough.
steps.description: Sift 3 cups of flour with the salt, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and garlic powder. Add the seasoned flour to the cheese mixture one large spoonful at a time. Beat every time you add more flour. Add the remaining flour to the mixture until it is somewhat stiff but still pliable. You may not need to use all of the flour. If the mixture gets to this point before you use the whole cup, stop adding the flour.

steps.headline: Make the straws.
steps.description: Pull off enough dough to make 1 inch (2.5 cm) balls. Roll them into a long strip. Flatten them into the shape of a straw with a fork, making long stripes down the side of them with the fork. Place them on the baking sheets until you have used all the dough. If you have a cookie press, attach the star tip. Put part of the dough into the cookie press. Push out long strips of the dough onto each of the baking sheets until they are filled and the dough is gone. This recipe yields 4 dozen. If you want to make less, cut the recipe in half to make 2 dozen.

steps.headline: Cook the straws.
steps.description: Cook the pans of straws for 20 minutes. They should be golden and crispy. If not, continue to cook until they are. Let them cool. Once they are cool, break them apart if they are too long. If you made the straws with the cookie press, you can break the long strips apart in 3 inch (7.6 cm) pieces.

methods.name: Baking Cheese Straws With Pastry Dough

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: Preheat the oven at 375 degrees. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper and set aside.

steps.headline: Shape the dough.
steps.description: Let your pastry dough thaw in the refrigerator overnight. Lightly flour your work surface. Roll out each sheet of dough until it is a 10 inch (25.4 cm) by 12 inch rectangle.

steps.headline: Make the straws.
steps.description: Beat the egg with 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) of water. Brush the mixture along the surface of the dough. Sprinkle half the Parmesan cheese, Gruyère cheese, thyme, salt, and pepper on each piece of pastry. Use a rolling pin to gently press the ingredients into the dough. Cut each sheet on the short side into 11 or 12 small strips with a pizza cutter or sharp knife. Twist each strip and lay them on the baking sheets. You should have 22-24 straws when done.

steps.headline: Cook the straws.
steps.description: Cook the straws for 10 to 15 minutes. They should be lightly brown and puffy. Turn each straw over and cook for another 2 minutes. Take them out and let them cool. Serve at room temperature. Make sure you do not overcook these. The cheese will burn.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: For this recipe, you need to preheat the oven at 350 degrees. Pull out a flat baking sheet and spray with nonstick spray. Set the pan aside.

steps.headline: Make the dough.
steps.description: Take the stale bread and crumble it in a medium bowl. Stir in the flour, cayenne pepper, and salt. Pour in the milk. It should start to feel like dough. Mix in the cheese. Knead the dough until the cheese is well mixed in. Since ingredients were rationed in the war, the amount of fresh flour is minimal. The use of stale bread allowed every resource to be used for something. If the mixture is too dry, add in a little milk at a time to thin it out.

steps.headline: Make the straws.
steps.description: Roll the dough until it is about a ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) thick. Cut the dough into strips that are 6 inches (15.2 cm) long and a 1/2 inch wide. You may need to dust your work surface with flour so the dough doesn't stick to it.

steps.headline: Cook the straws.
steps.description: Place the straws in the oven. Cook for 20 minutes. Remove them from the oven and let them cool before serving.

steps.headline: Mix the dough.
steps.description: Combine almond flour, coconut flour, arrowroot starch, xanthan gum, garlic powder, and salt in a large bowl. Add the butter a little at a time. Mix it until the mixture looks like crumbs. Add water 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) at a time until the mixture clumps together as dough. Form the dough into a flat disc and cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes. If you have a food processor, you can make the dough in it. Pulse the dry ingredients first. Add the butter and pulse until it crumbles. Then add the water as instructed.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: While you are waiting for the dough to chill, preheat the oven at 300 degrees. Take a large baking sheet and line it with parchment paper.

steps.headline: Make the straws.
steps.description: Take the dough out of the refrigerator. Roll 1 tablespoon of the dough into a thick stick with your hands. Place a piece of parchment paper on your work surface. Roll the dough until it is less than a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick and 7 to 8 inches (17.8 to 20.3 cm) long. Take 2 or 3 teaspoons of cheese and press it all around the dough until it sticks. Place it on the baking sheet. Repeat for all of the dough and cheese. If your straws break as you roll them out, piece them back together. Roll them again to smooth them out. Recipe makes 24 straws.

steps.headline: Cook the straws.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet of straws into the oven. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes. The straws should be firm and the cheese should be golden brown. Set them on a wire rack to cool. Let them cool completely before eating. Cooling the straws allows them to crisp all the way.

text: Cooking Cheese Straws From Scratch Preheat the oven. You need to preheat the oven at 325 degrees. Take 4 baking sheets and lightly spray them with cooking spray. Set them aside. Prepare the cheese. Leave your butter and cheese on the counter for a few hours to soften them. Once they are softened, put them in a large bowl. Using an electric mixer, beat the butter and cheese together until they look like cream cheese. This should take about 15-30 minutes. This is easiest if you have a standing mixer. This allows you to leave the mixture to beat instead of holding a hand mixer. Make the dough. Sift 3 cups of flour with the salt, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and garlic powder. Add the seasoned flour to the cheese mixture one large spoonful at a time. Beat every time you add more flour. Add the remaining flour to the mixture until it is somewhat stiff but still pliable. You may not need to use all of the flour. If the mixture gets to this point before you use the whole cup, stop adding the flour. Make the straws. Pull off enough dough to make 1 inch (2.5 cm) balls. Roll them into a long strip. Flatten them into the shape of a straw with a fork, making long stripes down the side of them with the fork. Place them on the baking sheets until you have used all the dough. If you have a cookie press, attach the star tip. Put part of the dough into the cookie press. Push out long strips of the dough onto each of the baking sheets until they are filled and the dough is gone. This recipe yields 4 dozen. If you want to make less, cut the recipe in half to make 2 dozen. Cook the straws. Cook the pans of straws for 20 minutes. They should be golden and crispy. If not, continue to cook until they are. Let them cool. Once they are cool, break them apart if they are too long. If you made the straws with the cookie press, you can break the long strips apart in 3 inch (7.6 cm) pieces. Baking Cheese Straws With Pastry Dough Preheat the oven. Preheat the oven at 375 degrees. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper and set aside. Shape the dough. Let your pastry dough thaw in the refrigerator overnight. Lightly flour your work surface. Roll out each sheet of dough until it is a 10 inch (25.4 cm) by 12 inch rectangle. Make the straws. Beat the egg with 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) of water. Brush the mixture along the surface of the dough. Sprinkle half the Parmesan cheese, Gruyère cheese, thyme, salt, and pepper on each piece of pastry. Use a rolling pin to gently press the ingredients into the dough. Cut each sheet on the short side into 11 or 12 small strips with a pizza cutter or sharp knife. Twist each strip and lay them on the baking sheets. You should have 22-24 straws when done. Cook the straws. Cook the straws for 10 to 15 minutes. They should be lightly brown and puffy. Turn each straw over and cook for another 2 minutes. Take them out and let them cool. Serve at room temperature. Make sure you do not overcook these. The cheese will burn. Making Wartime Cheese Straws Preheat the oven. For this recipe, you need to preheat the oven at 350 degrees. Pull out a flat baking sheet and spray with nonstick spray. Set the pan aside. Make the dough. Take the stale bread and crumble it in a medium bowl. Stir in the flour, cayenne pepper, and salt. Pour in the milk. It should start to feel like dough. Mix in the cheese. Knead the dough until the cheese is well mixed in. Since ingredients were rationed in the war, the amount of fresh flour is minimal. The use of stale bread allowed every resource to be used for something. If the mixture is too dry, add in a little milk at a time to thin it out. Make the straws. Roll the dough until it is about a ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) thick. Cut the dough into strips that are 6 inches (15.2 cm) long and a 1/2 inch wide. You may need to dust your work surface with flour so the dough doesn't stick to it. Cook the straws. Place the straws in the oven. Cook for 20 minutes. Remove them from the oven and let them cool before serving. Cooking Gluten Free Cheese Straws Mix the dough. Combine almond flour, coconut flour, arrowroot starch, xanthan gum, garlic powder, and salt in a large bowl. Add the butter a little at a time. Mix it until the mixture looks like crumbs. Add water 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) at a time until the mixture clumps together as dough. Form the dough into a flat disc and cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes. If you have a food processor, you can make the dough in it. Pulse the dry ingredients first. Add the butter and pulse until it crumbles. Then add the water as instructed. Preheat the oven. While you are waiting for the dough to chill, preheat the oven at 300 degrees. Take a large baking sheet and line it with parchment paper. Make the straws. Take the dough out of the refrigerator. Roll 1 tablespoon of the dough into a thick stick with your hands. Place a piece of parchment paper on your work surface. Roll the dough until it is less than a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick and 7 to 8 inches (17.8 to 20.3 cm) long. Take 2 or 3 teaspoons of cheese and press it all around the dough until it sticks. Place it on the baking sheet. Repeat for all of the dough and cheese. If your straws break as you roll them out, piece them back together. Roll them again to smooth them out. Recipe makes 24 straws. Cook the straws. Place the baking sheet of straws into the oven. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes. The straws should be firm and the cheese should be golden brown. Set them on a wire rack to cool. Let them cool completely before eating. Cooling the straws allows them to crisp all the way.
